description: Indicates the number of root blocker processes.
interpretation: Usually, the number of root blocker processes should be low. A sudden increase in this value, or a root-blocker process that has been blocking others for a long time, is a cause for concern. Detailed diagnosis typically shows the SPIDs, programs, and queries of these root-blocker processes. Terminating a long‑running root‑blocker often clears the blocking chain and restores normal database operation.
troubleshootingSteps: Use the detailed diagnosis or blocking views/DMVs to identify the root-blocker SPID, its login, host, and the exact query it is running.
Check whether the root-blocker is performing a legitimate long-running operation (such as maintenance or reporting) or is stuck due to a bad plan or waiting on an external resource.
If appropriate, tune or cancel the offending query (for example by adding indexes, rewriting the query, or changing isolation levels) so it can complete without causing prolonged blocking.
As a remediation of last resort, kill the confirmed root-blocker session, understanding that this will roll back its transaction and may impact users of that session.
Review application logic and transaction design to keep transactions short, avoid holding locks while waiting for user input, and reduce the likelihood of future root blockers.

description: Indicates the number of processes that are blocked by the root blockers.
interpretation: This measure shows how many sessions are currently unable to proceed because they are waiting on locks held by root-blocker processes. A higher value indicates broader impact from blocking. Detailed diagnosis can reveal which processes are blocked.
troubleshootingSteps: List all blocked sessions and identify what resources (tables, indexes, rows) they are waiting on and which root-blocker SPID is blocking them.
Prioritize investigation of blocked sessions that are business critical or have been blocked for a long time.
Determine whether the blocking is due primarily to write-heavy operations, missing indexes, or overly restrictive isolation levels, and address those root causes.
After resolving or killing the root-blocker, confirm that the number of blocked processes drops and that affected sessions can complete.
Implement monitoring and alerting on blocked process counts and durations so that future blocking storms are detected early.

description: Indicates the waiting time (blocked time) of the process or processes that were blocked for the maximum duration.
interpretation: If this value matches or exceeds the configured MAX BLOCKING TIME threshold, it indicates that one or more processes have been blocked for a very long time. Detailed diagnosis can be used to identify these long-blocked processes, who initiated them, and their resource usage, helping you pinpoint resource-heavy or misbehaving sessions.
troubleshootingSteps: Investigate any process whose blocked time approaches or exceeds the MAX BLOCKING TIME threshold and identify the blocking session responsible.
Check the workload and query text of long-blocked sessions to understand what they were attempting to do and whether they need to be retried or cancelled.
Analyze lock and wait statistics to determine whether certain tables, indexes, or application modules are consistently involved in long blocking chains.
Work with application owners to shorten transaction scopes, improve retry logic, and avoid long-held locks that can cause extended blocking.
Tune indexing and query patterns on hot tables to reduce lock contention, and consider using appropriate isolation levels (for example, read committed snapshot) where suitable to lessen blocking.
